instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2877: What is 820-2877? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi guys, I''m struggling with troubleshooting on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B.
No visible damage, everything looks clean.
S5 rails are OK, but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0V
Any suggestion what I can check or MCP is dead? Board doesn't power on and magsafe LED is dim.
Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Post the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage first.
Do you get L7750 voltage?

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> must come on after pressing power button only.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

Did you try another DCIN board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.58V
L7750 - 0.91V 

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> stays low if I trigger <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>
I didn't find a good spot to probe <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>. This net is going only to <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1400</CHIP> and both are BGA's. I'm using OpenBoardView and this SW doesn't shows vias so I can't probe this net on via either.

I haven't tried another DCIN board. I can order one and try it, but since the input voltage looks good, I'm guessing the DCIN board is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I asked about DCIN board because of dim light you've mentioned.
It is not related with no power issue.

Post resistance to ground at L6995; ohm scale, not diode mode.

Check <SIGNAL>RTC_RST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
With the magsafe disconnected the L6995 has fluctuating resistance to GND. It starts around 200k and increases over time. With magsafe connected it is 14M.

<SIGNAL>RTC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.39V
<SIGNAL>SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 3.39V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"With magsafe connected it is 14M."
Measuring ohm scale (or diode mode) with power applied???
Oh, my god!!!

Can't catch any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (at same time)?
Be sure <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> stays high rest of the time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Nothing on  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> (CH2)  when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (CH3)

[ATTACH type="full" width="556px" alt="Tek000.png"]60830[/ATTACH]
[ATTACH type="full" width="556px"]60831[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Very likely bad MCP, considering its age.
Heat it to 180-200 degrees for 15-20s and check if symptom changes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I give up. This board is going to trash, I spent too much time on this one. I tried to reflow it, no luck. Thank you for your help!
